title: 108_hr1178
content: The "Physician Relief Act of 2003" is the short title of this Act, which aims to provide relief for physicians. The Congress finds that medical liability insurance premiums are increasing significantly, with rates predicted to rise by up to 50 percent in some specialties and regions. Jury awards in claims cases have also seen a 7 percent increase in 1999 compared to the previous year. The purpose of this Act is to implement health care liability reforms to protect access to good healthcare and relieve the burden on physicians caused by excessive medical malpractice claims and judgments. Physicians in various states are already facing a crisis with high insurance premiums, some paying over $200,000 a year for coverage. The Act aims to implement health care liability reforms to protect access to healthcare and relieve physicians from the burden of excessive medical malpractice claims. The Act implements health care liability reforms to protect access to healthcare and relieve physicians from excessive medical malpractice claims. Punitive damages in health care lawsuits require clear and convincing evidence of malicious intent or deliberate failure to avoid injury. No punitive damages can be awarded if no compensatory damages are awarded, and they cannot be initially demanded in a lawsuit. Amendments for punitive damages require court approval based on evidence presented. In health care lawsuits, punitive damages can only be awarded if there is clear evidence of malicious intent or deliberate failure to avoid injury. A separate proceeding is required to determine the amount of punitive damages, and only specific factors can be considered in deciding the amount. Evidence relevant only to punitive damages is inadmissible in proceedings for compensatory damages. When determining punitive damages, the severity of harm, duration of conduct, profitability, number of products sold, criminal penalties, and civil fines are considered. Punitive damages in health care lawsuits can be awarded up to two times the economic damages or $250,000, whichever is greater, without informing the jury of this limit. Tax credit for medical malpractice liability insurance premiums under SEC. 45G of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The medical malpractice liability insurance premium credit under section 45G of the Internal Revenue Code allows for a credit of up to $2,000 per covered physician for insurance coverage. This credit is treated as a business credit and cannot be carried back to previous years. No carryback of section 45G credit before effective date. Denial of double benefit for medical malpractice liability insurance premiums. No deduction allowed for portion of premiums. The portion of medical malpractice liability insurance premiums allowable as a deduction for the taxable year is equal to the credit allowable under section 45G. Controlled groups must follow specific rules. A conforming amendment is made to the table of sections. "Part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Code is amended by adding a new item at the end." The amendments made by this section apply to medical malpractice liability insurance premiums paid or incurred after the enactment date of this Act in taxable years ending after such date.
